Article Title: Facebook down: Users not able to login or send messages
Article Text:
Users took to X to report the outage

Facebook users worldwide faced disruptions on Thursday (February 27) morning as Meta's social media platform experienced a major outage. The issue, which began at 7:36 AM, left users unable to access their feeds, send messages, or log in to their accounts.According to DownDetector, reports of the outage surged to over 18,000, with the majority of issues affecting the website. Users encountered an error message stating, "Sorry, something went wrong. We're working on getting this fixed as soon as we can". While the website was down, Facebook's mobile app appeared to function normally, allowing users to browse and interact without issues.As per DownDetector 82% users are not able to access the Facebook website, while only 10% and 7% users faced login and app issues respectively. The outage also impacted Facebook Messenger and Instagram messaging services, preventing users from sending messages for about an hour. Despite the widespread disruptions, Meta has yet to issue a formal statement on the cause of the outage.Facebook users took to X (formerly Twitter) to share their experiences and check if others were facing similar problems. Screenshots of the error message flooded the platform as speculation about the cause of the outage spread. Here are some postsReports of outages began declining about 30 minutes after their peak at 1 PM EST, suggesting that services were gradually being restored.
Article Summary: Facebook users worldwide faced disruptions on Thursday (February 27) morning as Meta's social media platform experienced a major outage. The issue, which began at 7:36 AM, left users unable to access their feeds, send messages, or log in to their accounts. Article Title: Slack restores service after major outage, but some users still face issues
Article Text:
Is Slack down today? Users report major outage and connection issues on February 26

Slack, the workplace messaging platform, has restored its services after a significant outage that affected users worldwide. However, some users are still experiencing login issues and other problems.The outage, which began around 10:30 AM ET on February 26, 2025, left thousands of users unable to send messages, load channels, or maintain connectivity. According to DownDetector, over 3,000 reports were logged from the US alone, with major disruptions also reported in Canada, the United Kingdom, and parts of Europe.Slack acknowledged the issue on its official status page and confirmed that their engineering team was investigating the root cause. The company has since restored full functionality to most affected features, including sending messages, workflows, threads, and other API-related functions. However, some users may still encounter issues with logging in, loading workspaces, and using certain features.In a statement, Slack said, "We identified the cause of the issue and are continuing to monitor our health metrics, but we are still not fully resolved. Some users may still reproduce symptoms such as issues loading their workspaces. Our work is still ongoing to restore affected backend services to returning functionality to impacted features”.As Slack continues to address the remaining issues, users are advised to monitor the company's official status page for real-time updates and follow recommended troubleshooting steps, such as refreshing the app or browser.For now, Slack has apologised for the inconvenience and assured users that they are working diligently to restore full service as soon as possible.

Article Title: Indonesia allows Apple to sell iPhone 16 in the country, but on these terms
Article Text: Indonesia will soon lift its ban on the iPhone 16, ending a months-long standoff with Apple after the tech giant agreed to invest more than $300 million in the Southeast Asian nation, Indonesia's Industry Minister announced Wednesday.The ban, imposed in October 2024, stemmed from Apple's failure to meet Indonesia's requirements that smartphones sold domestically contain at least 40% locally-produced components. After what Minister Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita described as "tricky" negotiations, both sides have reached an agreement.As part of the deal, Apple will invest in a software research and development center near Jakarta and establish manufacturing facilities to produce components for its products, including AirTags and AirPods. Reports indicate Apple will invest approximately $1 billion overall, with up to 20% of global AirTag production eventually taking place in Indonesia."There's a principle of justness that we're trying to uphold," Kartasasmita said at a press conference. "As much as it can add value to the red and white," he added, referencing the Indonesian flag.The agreement represents a partial retreat by Indonesian authorities, who had initially pressed Apple to manufacture iPhones locally. Instead, Apple will focus on producing accessories and investing in local talent development through training programs and coding academies.The ban had blocked Apple from selling its latest smartphones in a market of approximately 280 million people, though the company was already struggling to gain traction there. According to research firm Canalys, Apple wasn't among the top five smartphone brands in Indonesia during the third quarter of 2024, trailing Oppo, Xiaomi, Transsion, Samsung, and Vivo.No specific timeline was given for when the iPhone 16 will officially return to Indonesian stores, but the minister indicated Apple is now in the process of obtaining the necessary local content certification.
Article Summary: Indonesia will soon lift its ban on the iPhone 16, ending a months-long standoff with Apple. The tech giant agreed to invest more than $300 million in the Southeast Asian nation. The ban, imposed in October 2024, stemmed from Apple's failure to meet Indonesia's requirements.

Article Title: Amazon announces Alexa+, takes on OpenAI’s ChatGPT and Google Gemini
Article Text:
People attend an event where Amazon on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025, unveiled a generative-AI infused Alexa that it says will allow the popular voice assistant to have more personality, check a user’s tone and even plan romantic dates. (AP Photo/Wyatte Grantham-Philips)

Amazon unveiled Alexa+, its long-awaited AI-powered voice assistant, on Wednesday after more than a year of delays. The upgraded assistant will be available in the coming weeks in the US, and Prime members can have it for free or others can pay $19.99 monthly for it.The new assistant represents a complete redesign, transforming Alexa from a simple command-response tool into a conversational AI agent capable of autonomously completing complex tasks. Alexa+ can make restaurant reservations, order groceries, control smart home devices , and navigate web services with minimal user supervision."Until this moment – right this moment — we have been limited by the technology," said Panos Panay, Amazon's SVP of Devices & Services, during the New York launch event.Originally announced in September 2023, Alexa+ faced significant development hurdles that pushed its release from early 2024 to now. Internal testing reportedly revealed problems with accuracy and functionality that required extensive revisions.The assistant combines multiple AI models, including Amazon's Nova model and others from companies like Anthropic. It integrates with numerous third-party services such as OpenTable, Spotify, Grubhub, Uber Eats, and Ticketmaster.Amazon will begin rolling out early access next month, prioritizing Echo Show 8, 10, 15, and 21 device owners. The assistant will be accessible through compatible Echo devices , a new mobile app, and a browser-based experience at Alexa.com.The Alexa+ positions Amazon against competitive AI offerings including OpenAI's ChatGPT, Google's Gemini, and Apple's forthcoming Siri improvements, but it has an advantage here – about 600 million Alexa devices already in homes, and Amazon hopes this upgrade will revitalize its consumer electronics division, which has reportedly struggled to generate significant revenue despite widespread adoption.
Article Summary: Alexa+ can make restaurant reservations, order groceries, control smart home devices and navigate web services with minimal user supervision. The upgraded assistant will be available in the coming weeks in the US, and Prime members can have it for free or others can pay $19.99 monthly.

Encrypted messaging platform Telegram has been fined nearly $1 million (AUD 957,780) by Australia’s eSafety Commission for failing to respond in time to questions regarding its measures to combat terrorism and child abuse material on its platform. The Australian regulator had issued an information request in May 2024, requiring Telegram to report back by October 2024 on steps taken to tackle terrorist content and child exploitation material. However, Telegram took 160 days to respond, significantly obstructing the regulator's ability to assess online safety risks.The fine marks a significant move by Australia’s online safety regulator, which has been tightening its scrutiny of tech platforms to ensure compliance with the Online Safety Act . The penalty comes amid growing global concerns over the misuse of encrypted platforms for criminal activities, as well as increasing regulatory pressure on technology companies to cooperate with law enforcement.The Australian eSafety Commission issued infringement notices to multiple companies, including Telegram, Meta, WhatsApp, Google, and Reddit, in May 2024. These notices sought detailed information on how these platforms were handling violent extremist material and child sexual abuse content.Telegram failed to respond within the mandatory timeline, delaying its submission by nearly five months (160 days). As a result, the eSafety Commission imposed a fine of AUD 957,780 under the provisions of the Online Safety Act.eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant emphasized the importance of transparency and accountability from tech companies.she said in a statement.She further criticized Telegram’s delayed response, stating that it had hindered the eSafety Commission's ability to fulfill its role under the Online Safety Act for almost half a year.Telegram has 28 days to either:A spokesperson for Telegram described the fine as "unfair and disproportionate", indicating that the company intends to appeal the decision.If Telegram fails to comply, the eSafety Commission may escalate the case by:In a joint statement issued in 2024, intelligence agencies from the Five Eyes Alliance (United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand) highlighted Telegram as a platform where young people were accessing extremist propaganda videos.Australian authorities have expressed concerns that radicalizing content on encrypted messaging platforms could lead to violence, terrorism, and other online harms.said Julie Inman Grant.Telegram's regulatory challenges have intensified since its CEO, Pavel Durov, was arrested in France in August 2024 on charges related to failing to curb terrorist and extremist content.Durov was released on bail but remains banned from leaving France until the case is heard. Reports indicate that the legal proceedings could take up to a year before reaching a verdict.Since Durov’s arrest, Telegram has been making efforts to be more transparent, including releasing annual reports on law enforcement requests.Following the increased scrutiny, Telegram recently released its 2024 transparency report, which provided insight into its cooperation with law enforcement agencies.According to the report, in 2024:Despite these measures, the eSafety Commission remains concerned about Telegram’s overall compliance and response times when addressing online safety concerns.Telegram is not the only platform under scrutiny. The eSafety Commission is also set to release a report in March 2025 detailing how companies such as Meta, WhatsApp, Google, and Reddit have responded to online safety concerns.In a separate but related development, tech billionaire Elon Musk’s social media platform X (formerly Twitter) was also issued a notice to disclose its actions against terrorist content.Unlike Telegram, X appealed the notice to Australia’s Administrative Review Tribunal, with the case still ongoing. Additionally, X was fined over AUD 610,000 for failing to adequately respond to previous regulatory notices. The company is currently involved in multiple lawsuits over these fines.

If you’re a retail trader using broker APIs to automate trades, you can do so as long as your order frequency is below an exchange-prescribed threshold. This limit is yet to be decided.

If you’re selling algos or strategies to other traders, you’ll need to partner with a broker and get yourself registered with the exchanges to do so.

Marketplaces, where people share algos for a fee, can’t publish strategies without exchange registration as well as an RA license.

The exchanges will publish their own circulars with operational details by April 1.”

SEBI's latest ALGO trading rules | The Daily Brief #163

What SEBI’s new algo trading rules say



Zerodha co-founder and CEO Nithin Kamath is helping traders understand the Securities and Exchange Board of India 's (SEBI) new rules. In a post shared on social media platform X (earlier Twitter), Kamath explained SEBI ’s new regulations concerning algorithmic trading for retail investors, a move that significantly alters market participation. Kamath highlighted that retail traders selling trading strategies or algorithms must now partner with a broker and register with stock exchanges. Furthermore, platforms facilitating the sharing of algorithms for a fee will need both exchange registration and a research analyst (RA) licence.In the X post, Kamath wrote:In the comment section of the post, he also shared the link to an article which explains the latest SEBI algo trading regulations in details.SEBI’s newly announced framework will allow retail investors to engage in algo trading—an opportunity previously limited to institutional players. The move comes in response to rising demand from retail participants and aims to strike a balance between accessibility and risk management.Under the updated regulations, brokers must secure exchange approval for each algorithm and ensure that all automated orders include a unique identifier for audit tracking. Any modifications to an approved algorithm will also require regulatory clearance. Retail investors developing their algorithms will only need to register them if their order execution frequency exceeds a specified threshold.SEBI has categorised algorithms into two types: “white box” algos, where the logic is transparent and replicable, and “black box” algos, which operate without disclosure. Providers of black box algos will be required to obtain a Research Analyst (RA) license and maintain detailed research documentation.Set to take effect on August 1, these new rules are expected to transform India’s algo trading landscape—expanding automation for retail traders while introducing stricter compliance measures to uphold market integrity .

Article Title: SEBI fines the 'She Wolf of Stock Market': Gave anauthorised ...
Article Text:
SEBI’’s action against Asmita Patel

Asmita Patel accused of re-routing money

Securities & Exchange Board of India ( SEBI ) has seized Rs 53.67 crore from Asmita Patel Global School of Trading Pvt Ltd along with five other entities. Asmita Patel Global School of Trading Pvt Ltd is a well-known stock market training institute that offers online courses on stocks and trading. Some of the popular courses offered by the self-proclaimed "options queen" and "She Wolf of Stock Market" are "Let's Make India Trade" (LMIT), "Master's in Price Action Trading" (MPAT), and "Options Multiplier" (OM) .Jayesh Thakkar, a SEBI Registered Research Analyst shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) stating “SEBI has seized Rs 53.67 crore that Asmita Patel and five other related entities made illegally. Asmita Patel is also at risk of losing another Rs 104.6 crore it collected from course fees, which SEBI believes were part of unregistered advisory services.”The investigation was initiated by SEBI after receiving complaints from 42 participants of these courses. In addition to impounding the Rs 53.67 crore, SEBI has issued a show-cause notice questioning why Rs 104.6 crore, collected as fees for various programs, should not also be seized.SEBI has sent an interim order directing the school, Asmita Jitesh Patel, and Jitesh Jethalal Patel to cease offering unregistered investment advisory and research analyst services. The entities have also been barred from accessing the securities market.The order also uncovered that fees collected from participants were routed through entities such as King Traders (proprietor: Sagar Dhanjibhai), Gemini Enterprise (proprietor: Suresh Parmashivam), and United Enterprises (proprietor: Jigar Rameshbhai Dawada). SEBI stated that this was a regular practice and not an isolated incident, making all six entities jointly and severally liable for the Rs 53.67 crore earned from course fees.The regulator further demanded that the notices explain why they should not be ordered to disgorge Rs 104.6 crore, along with interest. SEBI's order noted that the fees collected for LMIT, MPAT, and OM courses, as well as other programs provided by the school, were earned under the guise of unregistered advisory and research analyst services.The order reads, “The aforesaid amount includes not only the amount collected as fees by the Noticees for LMIT, MPAT and Options Multiplier (OM) courses but also includes the fees collected by the Noticees for the other courses offered by the Noticee no.1 (Asmita Patel Global School of Trading )through which it carried out unregistered investment advisory and research analyst services along with interest”.Kamlesh Varshney, SEBI's Whole-Time Member, highlighted in the order “Examination revealed that, prima facie, the Noticee no. 1 (Asmita Patel Global School of Trading) along with the Noticee no.2 (Asmita Jitesh Patel) and the Notice no.3 (Jitesh Jethalal Patel) devised a scheme wherein students/investors/participants were lured to trade in specific stocks and told to open trading account with ABC Ltd. Recommendations of buy/sell of specific securities were provided and uploaded on telegram channels owned by the Noticee no.1. The acts of the Noticee no.1 makes it evident that it was providing investment advice/ research analyst services to students/investors/participants for a consideration in the pretext of imparting education.”
Article Summary: Asmita Patel Global School of Trading Pvt Ltd is a well-known stock market training institute that offers online courses on stocks and trading. Article Title: Former Apple chief designer officer recalls his first task from Steve Jobs: ‘We started work on…what became…’
Article Text:
Representative Image

Former Apple chief designer officer Jony Ive recently appeared on the BBC’s Desert Island Discs podcast where he said that he was given ‘an impossible’ task by founder Steve Jobs the first time they met. Jobs returned to Apple in 1997 when the company was facing financial difficulties. The designer said that at the time, Apple secured a $150 million investment from Microsoft to stay afloat. The company needed a successful product, and Jobs assigned Ive to lead its design.Ive and his team started working on what would become the iMac . He said that personal computers were not common in households at the time, and many people found them difficult to use. The goal was to make the new computer more accessible."We started work from the first day that we met on what became the iMac," the designer said in the podcast.Ive explained that the team carefully considered every detail of the colorful PC lineup to make it more user-friendly. The handle, for instance, was a deliberate design element meant to give the iMac a distinct feature, making it more approachable for those unfamiliar with computers.“It references immediately and unambiguously your hand, and you understand, therefore, something about this object,” he said. Ive noted that features like the handle and translucent colors made the iMac more engaging for consumers than technical specifications like gigahertz and hard drive capacity. "It felt alive; it didn't static; it didn't feel stuck," he said.For those unaware, Apple launched the iMac in 1999 and sold 800,000 units within five months. The product debuted with the tagline “Collect all five.” After the iMac, Ive continued to work on Apple’s major products, including the iPhone and iPad. He eventually became the company’s Chief Design Officer. Apple later moved away from colorful designs, but in 2021, it reintroduced color options for the iMac. Ive left Apple in 2019 after 27 years with the company.
Article Summary: Former Apple chief designer officer Jony Ive recently appeared on the BBC’s Desert Island Discs podcast. He said that he was given ‘an impossible’ task by founder Steve Jobs the first time they met. Jobs returned to Apple in 1997 when the company was facing financial difficulties.

Article Title: Gastroenterologist Dr Prateek Sharma to join Indian research effort through VAIBHAV fellowship
Article Text: The Department of Science and Technology (DST) has announced the Vaishvik Bhartiya Vaigyanik (VAIBHAV) Fellowship, an initiative aimed at fostering collaboration between the Indian STEMM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics, and Medicine) diaspora and Indian research institutions. The programme seeks to bring top Indian-origin scientists, technologists, and researchers (NRI/OCI/PIO) to work with Indian academic and R&D institutions on cutting-edge research, fostering knowledge exchange and global best practices.The VAIBHAV Fellowship builds upon the success of the VAIBHAV Summit, inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, which saw participation from over 25,000 attendees, including members of the Indian STEMM diaspora from more than 70 countries.Implemented by the DST under the Ministry of Science and Technology, the fellowship is open to outstanding scientists of Indian origin engaged in research abroad. Selected fellows will be invited to collaborate with Indian institutions for up to two months per year, for a maximum of three years. The fellowship includes a grant of Rs 4,00,000 per month, along with coverage for international and domestic travel, accommodation, and contingencies.As part of the programme, 75 distinguished fellows will be chosen to contribute to research across 18 pivotal domains, including quantum technology, healthcare and pharmaceuticals, electronics, computer sciences, agriculture, energy, and material sciences, among others.Among the shortlisted candidates is Dr Prateek Sharma, a Professor of Medicine and Director of the GI Fellowship programme at the University of Kansas School of Medicine, who also holds the titles of MD, FASGE, FACP, and FACG. Dr Prateek Sharma also holds the prestigious title of Elaine Blaylock Endowed Professor at the Kansas University Cancer Center. He completed his internal medicine residency at the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee and pursued a gastroenterology fellowship at the University of Arizona in Tucson.Dr Prateek Sharma's proposed research focuses on improving the early detection of esophageal and gastric cancers in India using AI-augmented upper GI endoscopy. These cancers are among the leading causes of cancer-related deaths in the country, and early diagnosis is crucial for improving survival rates. While traditional endoscopy often misses early-stage cases, AI-assisted endoscopy has shown promising results in enhancing detection and outcomes in Western studies.Dr. Sharma, who has played a key role in developing and validating AI-driven endoscopy in the U.S., will guide the implementation of this cutting-edge technology in India, where it is currently unavailable. The project aims to leverage patient health data—including medical records, pathology reports, radiology images, and endoscopic findings—to develop a composite risk score and a digital health tool powered by machine learning algorithms.Building on pilot work already initiated by AIIMS, New Delhi, particularly in diet and nutrition data collection, the research will focus on integrating AI-assisted endoscopy for risk stratification and personalised interventions. The ultimate goal is to enhance patient prognosis, increase treatment success rates, and reduce mortality associated with GI cancers in India. The project’s success is expected to make a significant impact in gastroenterology and oncology, paving the way for AI-driven healthcare solutions and improving cancer care nationwide.
Article Summary: The Department of Science and Technology (DST) has announced the Vaishvik Bhartiya Vaigyanik (VAIBHAV) Fellowship. The initiative is aimed at fostering collaboration between the Indian STEMM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics, and Medicine) diaspora and Indian research institutions.

Article Title: Accenture onboards agents; AI transition reshapes job roles
Article Text: Mumbai: With the transition from traditional AI models to autonomous AI systems , the role of AI practitioners is changing. Accenture 's analysis highlights emerging competencies that build upon the established R12 (required 12) framework, aimed at creating a workforce ready for future AI developments. "AI is breaking the code on action and intelligence. Organisations are going to rewire themselves and reinvent themselves. It is a huge opportunity to do that now. Globally, over 50,000 people were trained on the Agentic AI platform , and many of them are based in India," said Senthil Ramani, lead – data & AI for Accenture. He spoke to TOI on the sidelines of the Nasscom Technology & Leadership Forum 2025 in Mumbai on Tuesday.Recently, Accenture designed a platform—AI Refinery—to onboard agents to work alongside software professionals. The platform caters to 12 industry sectors to help firms rapidly build and deploy a network of AI agents.Ramani emphasised that it is crucial for companies to structure and arrange their data layer effectively. "Firms need to engage in dialogue with data. By dialogue with data, I mean that when you are in an enterprise and you really want a business to use many of the AI models you create, it is essential to facilitate effective communication with data. If businesses can effectively dialogue with data, then you have already achieved your purpose because you have diffused AI, and they are already using your models," Ramani said.He highlighted roles with additional responsibilities that would be reshaping skills in an AI-first world. He said the role of a data engineer is evolving from primarily building data pipelines for data extraction and cleansing to using Gen AI for data engineering. This includes automating and building data products, using GenAI agents for data quality engineering, and employing AI for data governance.The responsibilities of an AI/ML computational scientist are transforming significantly. Rather than relying solely on traditional AI/ML methodologies for model development and training, the focus has shifted towards utilising GenAI with retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). This advancement enables professionals to create and deploy Gen AI agents, leading to comprehensive process innovations.The role of an LLM (large language model) architect will now evolve from designing an architecture for LLM model usage to designing an architecture for agents where the parameters of multi-LLM environments and autonomous action will need to be addressed.Full stack developers specialising in LLLMs will broaden their scope beyond creating language models. Their expertise will encompass the development of self-governing systems, where smart agents possess the capability to execute real-time decision-making, demonstrate adaptability and perform independent actions.In response to the rapid strides in AI, the interconnection among different teams has become increasingly vital. AI specialists, data analysts, business professionals, and governance experts function cohesively, moving away from siloed operational approaches.
Article Summary: Senthil Ramani, lead – data & AI for Accenture, spoke to TOI on the sidelines of the Nasscom Technology & Leadership Forum 2025 in Mumbai on Tuesday. He highlighted roles with additional responsibilities that would be reshaping skills in an AI-first world. Ramani emphasised that it is crucial for companies to structure and arrange their data layer effectively.

Article Title: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu sparks debate with his "Let us learn Hindi” tip for workers in Tamil Nadu
Article Text: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu has sparked a fresh debate on language in India by encouraging Tamil Nadu's workforce to learn Hindi to better serve customers across northern markets, particularly in Mumbai, Delhi, and Gujarat.In a post on X (formerly Twitter), Vembu emphasized the practical business benefits of language flexibility , noting that rural jobs in Tamil Nadu depend on effectively serving Hindi-speaking customers. "Not knowing Hindi is often a serious handicap for us in Tamil Nadu," Vembu stated, adding that he has personally begun learning Hindi, now understanding about 20% of spoken Hindi after five years of study.Zoho Chief Scientist urged Tamils to set aside political considerations and embrace Hindi learning as a smart business strategy in India's rapidly growing economy. He concluded his message with the same encouragement in both Tamil and Hindi: "Let us learn Hindi!"Vembu's comments have generated mixed reactions online. Some supporters agreed that Hindi should serve as "India's common denominator and business language of choice," questioning why some prefer English over a native Indian language.One user replied to Vembu, asking why Hindi speakers couldn't learn English instead, with one commenter noting, "Sir, they can learn English to communicate. But, why are they insisting that we learn Hindi?"Others suggested a more balanced approach, pointing out that "People should learn language to get ahead. People should also learn Tamil or Kannada if they want good jobs in tech as most of the jobs is in Bengaluru and Chennai."This isn't the first time Vembu has waded into language debates. In November 2024, he sparked controversy by stating that residents of Bengaluru should learn Kannada, calling it "disrespectful" not to learn the local language after living in the city for years. That statement similarly divided online opinion, with some supporting his stance on respecting local languages while others disagreed with his perspective.
Article Summary: Zoho founder Sridhar Vembu urges Tamil Nadu's workforce to learn Hindi. He says rural jobs in Tamil Nadu depend on effectively serving Hindi-speaking customers. His comments have generated mixed reactions online, with some supporting his stance on respecting local languages.

Article Title: Cognizant is no longer at bottom of stack: CEO Ravi Kumar
Article Text: Mumbai: It's now two years since Ravi Kumar took charge as CEO of Cognizant, and some metrics suggest he's pulling the company out of the trough it had fallen into. Kumar said Cognizant has moved to the ‘middle of the stack’ among its peers, after remaining at the bottom - an apparent reference to the company doing better than Capgemini, Wipro and Tech Mahindra in the latest quarter. “I'm not saying I'm going to be in the top three this year, but I've directionally moved up. From the middle of the stack to the top of the stack is harder because now you must compete with performing companies. I have all the machinery aligned to be a market leader, and that's why I feel confident about it,” Kumar said at the Nasscom Technology & Leadership Forum 2025 in Mumbai on Tuesday.Peers like Accenture, TCS and Infosys are continuing to do better than Cognizant, which registered a 2% organic growth in the quarter ended December.In the last two calendar years, the Nasdaq-listed firm experienced a decline in organic revenue. Last year, Cognizant spent $1.7 billion to buy Belcan, a US engineering R&D services firm, and Thirdera, a ServiceNow partner specialising in advisory, implementation, and optimisation solutions. Those acquisitions ensured a positive overall revenue growth in 2024.Kumar said he has improved significantly on the number of large deals signed - in the December quarter, Cognizant signed ten large deals with a total contract value of more than $100 million. He said Cognizant's two core verticals - healthcare and BFSI - are doing better than previously. He also said he has diversified the business, both in terms of industry verticals, and horizontal services, thereby bringing greater resilience to the firm. He said the task of geographic diversification will take longer. Accenture, TCS, Infosys, and Wipro have been far more diversified than Cognizant, which is heavily dependent on healthcare and BFSI, and on the US market.“We're starting to enter a growth phase. We achieved organic year-on-year growth last quarter, and we are guided for organic growth this quarter too. There are places where we are not doing well and areas where it’s work in progress. We have a margin expansion plan. We are no longer a company sitting on the side,” Kumar said.He said Cognizant improved employee utilisation, directly impacting the bottom line. It also implemented AI-driven productivity measures. He said with machines writing 20% of the code, teams can accomplish more tasks with fewer personnel. This, Kumar said, creates an interesting economic scenario known as Jevons Paradox, where increased efficiency in resource usage leads to higher overall demand for that resource. In AI's case, the efficiency it brings is enabling a lot more to be accomplished using AI, thereby increasing its use.Asked about Elon Musk's DOGE initiative and its impact on Belcan, which executes many US federal projects, Kumar said, “There is no impact there. On the government side, they work on defence and submarines. They don't do federal work. I have not seen an impact on spending. But I can't predict what the future is going to be.”
Article Summary: Cognizant registered a 2% organic growth in the quarter ended December. In the last two calendar years, the Nasdaq-listed firm experienced a decline in organic revenue. Last year, Cognizant spent $1.7 billion to buy Belcan and Thirdera.

Article Title: Facebook-parent Meta faces lawsuit over hiring practices in US
Article Text:
What is Meta accused of



Meta denies allegations

Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, is facing a lawsuit alleging that it prefers hiring foreign workers over American citizens because they can be paid less. A US federal judge, according to Reuters, has ruled that the lawsuit can move forward, allowing three US citizens to pursue a proposed class action against the company. The lawsuit is filed under the case name Rajaram et al v Meta Platforms Inc in the US District Court for the Northern District of California, with case number 22-02920.The lawsuit was filed by three individuals: IT worker Purushothaman Rajaram, software engineer Ekta Bhatia, and data scientist Qun Wang. All three are naturalized US citizens who claim they applied for multiple jobs at Meta between 2020 and 2024 but were rejected due to what they describe as Meta’s "systematic preference" for hiring visa holders instead of American workers.US Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler in San Francisco pointed to statistics showing that 15% of Meta’s US workforce holds H-1B visas, which are typically given to foreign professionals, while only 0.5% of the overall workforce in the country has such visas. She also referenced Meta’s 2021 agreement to pay up to $14.25 million, including a fine, to settle US government claims that it routinely ignored American workers for jobs set aside for temporary visa holders.Meta has dismissed the claims as baseless and stated that it will continue to defend itself in court. The company argued that there is no evidence it intended to discriminate or that the plaintiffs would have been hired if they were not US citizens.
Article Summary: A US federal judge ruled that the lawsuit can move forward, allowing three US citizens to pursue a proposed class action against the company. The lawsuit was filed by three individuals: IT worker Purushothaman Rajaram, software engineer Ekta Bhatia, and data scientist Qun Wang. All three are naturalized US citizens who claim they applied for multiple jobs at Meta between 2020 and 2024 but were rejected due to Meta’s "systematic preference" for hiring visa holders.

Article Title: White House clears one of the 'biggest unknown' around DOGE, and it does 'not have' Elon Musk

Between government roles, she worked as chief product officer at healthcare startups Russell Street Ventures and Main Street Health, both founded by Brad Smith, who worked in Trump 's first administration.White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt had earlier refused to identify DOGE's administrator from the podium, telling reporters only that "career officials and political appointees" were helping run the department alongside Musk, who serves as a special government employee and advisor to President Donald Trump The clarification comes amid growing scrutiny of DOGE's operations, including legal challenges from state attorneys general and reports that 21 USDS employees resigned Tuesday in protest of what they described as "significant security risks" created by the agency. Musk, despite not being the formal administrator, will attend Trump's first cabinet meeting alongside confirmed department secretaries.
